appearances.title: Ana Cabrera Reports : MSNOW : January 15, 2026 7:00am-9:00am PST
appearances.snippet: let's discuss this and more with democratic congressman glenn ivey from maryland.about the trump administration's immigration crackdown there and its handling of protesters. congressman, a lot of simmering tensions in minnesota this morning. we showed the images from overnight, the tear gas, the sparks flying. the president just threatened to institute the insurrection act. is there anything you've seen that's led you to believe there's an insurrection going on? >> no, as a matter of fact, it's a, i think, a dangerous and illegal escalation of the situation. you've got people out there exercising their first amendment rights and in a nonviolent way, as far as i can tell. and certainly they have the right to do that. this is just an attempt to sort of intimidate them and push back. same thing when they surged up more ice agents a few days ago. and the threats about insurrection act aren't new. they use those, i believe it was last summer when they were talking about putting national guard into cities. so the irony is, you know, we needed the national guard to be cal

appearances.title: Laura Coates Live : CNNW : January 16, 2026 8:00pm-9:00pm PST
appearances.snippet: i want to bring in congressman glenn ivey of maryland. he's one of several democrats who traveled to minneapolis today for a field hearing on what was going on there. he also served as a former u.s. attorney right here as well in d.c. and i'm curious, your impression, given the pattern that is obviously emerged, but also the inkblot test that people are trying to say is existing when it comes to what's happening with the surge. what is your reaction to the doj investigating either the governor of minnesota or the mayor of minneapolis? >> it looks ridiculous on its face. frankly, it's starting to remind me a little bit of the nixon enemies list, but it's a little worse, actually, because they're actually moving forward. he's he's turned the department of justice into the department of retribution. and so i think it's being abused, and i think people see that. the problem, though, is, you know, in minnesota, we went up there today and instead of the prosecutors investigating the shooting that took place, for example, you had the sixth, assi

appearances.title: U.S. House of Representatives : CSPAN : January 6, 2026 6:29pm-8:20pm EST
appearances.snippet: gentlelady for remarks, and i now yield one minute to the gentleman from maryland, representative glenn ivey. >> i thank my distinguished colleague from south carolina and certainly my distinguished colleague from maryland, for giving us the opportunity to speak on this issue tonight. uh, the fifth anniversary of that tragic day, uh, of the attack on this capitol. i want to focus on two men who were here that day. uh, one was nathan tate. he was a police officer who'd grown up in prince george's county. he had mixed feelings about what the police do. uh, because he'd had some bad experience in his childhood and in his neighborhood. but he decided he could make a difference. he felt called to public service as a police officer. and when he went to work, he joined the metropolitan police department in washington, d.c. and was sent to some of the toughest neighborhoods in washington, where i'd actually been a prosecutor many years before. on that tragic day, he was one of the 140 officers who were attacked and injured. fortunately, he was not one of the four who died that day, and another one d
